qas.question: What is the title of the book published by Robert T. Bakker regarding mainstream opinion of dinosaurs?
What criticism did Robert T. Bakker share about the paleontologist community regarding the last fifty years?

answers.text: the field hasn't tested dinosaur orthodoxy severely enough

qas.question: What film did Robert T. Bakker's book reportedly influence?
What type of poses did the book's illustrations portray dinosaurs as?
What label is associated with Robert T. Bakker as a result of his work?
Who is a modern example of an exoheretic?
What film did Bakker base his book off of?
What did Bakker criticize the paleontology community for spenting fifty years testing?
What did Bakker see as destabalizing?

context: The revisionist paleontologist <b5_0>Robert T. Bakker<b5_0/>, who published his findings as <a0_0>The Dinosaur Heresies<a0_0/>, treated the mainstream view of dinosaurs as dogma. "I have enormous respect for dinosaur paleontologists past and present. But on average, for the last fifty years, <a1_0>the field hasn't tested <b7_0>dinosaur orthodoxy<b7_0/> severely enough<a1_0/>." page 27 "Most taxonomists, however, have viewed such <b8_0>new terminology<b8_0/> as dangerously destabilizing to the traditional and well-known scheme..." page 462. This book apparently influenced <a2_0><b6_0>Jurassic Park<b6_0/><a2_0/>. The illustrations by the author show dinosaurs in very <a3_0>active poses<a3_0/>, in contrast to the traditional perception of lethargy. He is an example of a recent scientific <a4_0>endoheretic<a4_0/>.
